title: Business Live: Pound slips back
text:
Getty Images Copyright: Getty Images

The world's top rugby nations are poised for the start of the Rugby World Cup. The tournament kicks off in Japan today, and organisers say the economic benefit to the country will be huge.

They expect it will bring in around $4bn (£3.2bn), with more than 500,000 foreign visitors in town for the 6-week event.

But one issue is worrying some Japanese bars – the risk they might run out of beer.

Organisers reportedly held sessions with local firms about the possibility of a "beer crisis" and how to prepare for the onslaught of beer-guzzling fans.

At venues used during 2015 Rugby World Cup in England, rugby fans consumed 1.9 million litres of beer - six times the amount consumed on average by football fans in those same venues.
description: The pound is giving up its gains against the dollar ahead of talks between Stephen Barclay and Michel Barnier.
